description: From Middle English slappen, of uncertain origin, possibly imitative. Compare Low German Slappe (“slap”), whence also German Schlappe (“defeat”). Compare also Italian sleppa (“slap”).

examples: He tossed the file down slap in the middle of the table.

entries.meaning: (countable) A blow, especially one given with the open hand, or with something broad and flat.
examples: He gave me a friendly slap on the back as a sign of camaraderie.

entries.meaning: (countable) A sharp percussive sound like that produced by such a blow.
examples: the slap of my feet on the bathroom tiles

entries.meaning: (countable, music) The percussive sound produced in slap bass playing.

examples: If you had too much slap on when you went out . . . your mates say too much slap on your ecaf. Yeah. Oh really girl? Yes . . . Go in the lavs here and have a look.

entries.meaning: (slang, countable) An eye-catching sticker used in street art.
examples: […]  which seek to retake public space for their own expression, using graffiti, stickering, 'slaps' and street art to dissent from the commercialisation of the public sphere.

verbs.description: slap (third-person singular simple present slaps, present participle slapping, simple past and past participle slapped)

examples: She slapped him in response to the insult.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause something to strike soundly.
examples: He slapped the reins against the horse's back.
The rain slapped against the window-panes.
We'd better slap some fresh paint on that wall.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal, figurative) To impose a penalty, etc. on (someone).
examples: I was slapped with a parking fine.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To play slap bass on (an instrument).
